1117928633971068935.text: Let's Encrypt to transition to ISRG roothttps://scotthelme.co.uk/lets-encrypt-to-transition-to-isrg-root/ …

1117927796121018368.text: Too much to continue tweeting, so I wrote a blog post:https://scotthelme.co.uk/lets-encrypt-to-transition-to-isrg-root/ …

1117903730169368576.text: It's created by @ivanristic and delivered via @feistyduck, and one of the topics include the @letsencrypt cross-sign specifically!pic.twitter.com/idf5L542sq

1117903281236262912.text: If you're interested in details like this about certificates/TLS, I deliver a 2-day training course called "The Best TLS Training in the World" which you'd enjoy: https://www.feistyduck.com/training/the-best-ssl-and-tls-training-in-the-world …

1117902517809991680.text: This same trait will also prevent breakage for sites/services that have hardcoded the old, cross-signed X3 and will soon fetch new certs signed with the ISRG-signed X3. New certs issued can chain back to the IdenTrust root through the cross-sign.

1117901913599512576.text: Simple fix if this is a concern: continue to serve the old, cross-signed intermediate. The cross-signed X3 and the ISRG-signed X3 are both using the same key pair, so certificates issued from the ISRG X3 can build a chain through the cross-sign to IdenTrust's root.

1117901004580605952.text: The new intermediate will be delivered automatically via ACME and only site operators with legacy clients will need to consider taking any action. If the client has not been updated to include the ISRG root, it's likely that chain building will fail.

1117899851876823040.text: Let's Encrypt announce plans to transition from their cross-signed intermediate on July 8th 2019 and chain to the ISRG root. https://letsencrypt.org/2019/04/15/transitioning-to-isrg-root.html … @letsencrypt

1114581837664403456.text: Not only that but look inside... The OEM cat is 400 cell (CPSI/cells per square inch) and look at that nasty, sharp lip right on the entry to disrupt flow... 1114580665402634240.text: With a high-flow sports cat I can run more boost with less turbo lag. Notice how the new cat has less restrictive joints, maintaining at least 90mm diameter throughout to allow maximum gas flow. More flow = more boost = moar power!

1114580375550996481.text: Next hardware upgrade went in today, a new exhaust from Power Valve! The Stage 1 tune was great, but Stage 2 needs more hardware upgrades. Here's my old cat on top and new cat below. One of the most restrictive components in the exhaust which restricts power/boost on turbo cars.pic.twitter.com/r7qKMakXLi

1110152486952857601.text: A small company can't waste that kind of resource, so the answer is no, we haven't done any of the work! What happens if we crash out with no deal now? Race against the clock, seriously modify billing system, re-register for VAT in [insert member state]...

1110151894176055296.text: The biggest problem overall is that we *still* just do not know what is happening and when. Do we need to put this enormous development effort into our billing system or not? Are we supposed to do that and throw it away if we remain or semi-remain with some kind of deal?

1110148759906848768.text: We also lose our digital services VAT threshold which requires further changes to our processes that are currently based on this existing.pic.twitter.com/PvYIWoYXo7

1110148496068349953.text: It's ok though, we can register in every independent EU member state if we want to...pic.twitter.com/Ya11ZEHZwM

1110148218271293441.text: This is a process that no one can tell us how long it will take, but we will be kicked out of VAT MOSS on April 1st and must be registered in another EU member state by April 10th, or, stop selling services into the EU?..

1110147847054340096.text: So basically, if this happens, we will be kicked out of the VAT MOSS scheme and have to re-register as a non-member state in some other EU country to be able to continue to sell into any EU member state.pic.twitter.com/RPYSCslYph

1110147407139008513.text: We need to update our billing system to check UK VAT numbers on a service that becomes available the day after this disaster happens......pic.twitter.com/H6FszA2Zwk

1110147221612302337.text: Rather than being able to submit a single, unified VAT return under VAT MOSS, we will have to register and apply for VAT refunds from each of the 28 member states individually! For a small, 4 person startup, that's outrageous.pic.twitter.com/jGZX6StuxB

1110146886479032320.text: We're caught by the first 3 requirements detailed here:pic.twitter.com/jOPDKgb9S2

1110146672049426433.text: It was hard enough for us to become VAT MOSS compliant to sell into the EU as a member state, but if we leave it's going to become *considerably* harder for us...https://scotthelme.co.uk/overcoming-the-hurdles-of-vat-and-vat-moss-in-the-eu/ …

1110146510694633472.text: Unbelieavable that we potentially have a *massive* ammount of work to do for @reporturi based on whether or not the UK leaves the EU without a deal in 4 DAYS from now.https://www.gov.uk/guidance/vat-it-system-rules-and-processes-if-the-uk-leaves-the-eu-without-a-deal …

1110126110463934465.text: Trying to communicate this to new and existing customers is an even bigger burden. All FR VAT numbers are currently being returned as invalid by VIES, breaking reverse charging: http://ec.europa.eu/taxation_customs/vies/vatResponse.html …

1108687673902944257.text: Each of these payloads requires schema validation, filtering, pre-processing and eventually, database activity. These aren't simple HTTP GET requests, they're POST requests with a payload!

The current stats for @reporturi show that in the last 24 hours we processed 537,723,567 JSON payloads from 8,042,544 unique visitors!pic.twitter.com/DWVelgk44N

1108662162711609345.text: They're either trying to hide public opinion or, more likely, can't keep a basic website online at an important time. Don't worry though, we've got this Brexit thing covered..

1108378002256216068.text: Update, I just got a response from DigiCert, confirming they revoked the cert:pic.twitter.com/B19rBxoKAD

1108362542164951041.text: We use PaperTrail for log centralisation and monitoring and have alerts setup for a variety of things that we really want to know about if they hit our logs. I just got a hit on our password alert and it's great to see our mitigation worked

1108362108893319174.text: Fortunately, it had never happened to us and we implemented a fix to prevent it ever happening. Had we not taken note of that event and investigated, it would have happened to us today for the first time.pic.twitter.com/0GZk56yAyD

1108361434227007489.text: In early 2018 both GitHub and Twitter had issues where they error logged user passwords in the clear. I wrote a blog post about how we took note of that event, learnt from their mistake and fixed the potential for it to happen to us at @reporturi.https://scotthelme.co.uk/when-logging-causes-security-incidents-what-we-learned-from-github-and-twitter/ …

1108358720499732480.text: The likelihood of that happening here is very low (probably non-existent) but it's a great demonstration of the value of FS and why a robust TLS config is essential. Key compromise can and does happen. I can't wait for TLSv1.3 where FS is mandatory

1108358203035869184.text: Given access to the key/cert an attacker can decrypt traffic on the network to their domain and impersonate them, but without Forward Secrecy on a connection an attacker can go back in time and decrypt historic, recorded traffic from before the compromise.https://scotthelme.co.uk/perfect-forward-secrecy/ …

1108357899875684352.text: Their @ssllabs score is a C, which isn't great, but in terms of issues directly related to this key compromise, the lack of robust Forward Secrecy support is an obvious problem. https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/analyze.html?d=sdbn.com&hideResults=on …pic.twitter.com/SOSbbRRwgh

1108357610217054210.text: In terms of impact it's really hard to say. There is obviously the purchase/installation of a new cert and this incident of course doesn't look good, but what about security/privacy implications?

1108351515369095168.text: Perhaps interesting to note their 2017-2018 certificate was using the same key as their 2018-2019 certificate. You should really be regenerating new keys with new certificates, especially if they're a 12 month EV certificate. Here's their previous cert: https://crt.sh/?id=258649124 pic.twitter.com/4JT5pQaGOB

1108350922630008833.text: The replacement certificate has been issued against a new key:pic.twitter.com/9ygZZlYLNa

1108350402687307776.text: According to the Baseline Requirements the CA 'MUST' revoke this certificate within 24 hours of being notified of a key compromise. DigiCert have met that requirement quite comfortably. https://cabforum.org/wp-content/uploads/CA-Browser-Forum-BR-1.6.4.pdf …pic.twitter.com/O6chQt1KiP

1108349484856168448.text: A replacement cert has been issued and is now deployed on the site, so DigiCert must have succeeded in contacting the company, having the key/cert taken down and having the new ones installed. https://crt.sh/?id=1298806645 pic.twitter.com/AH2NghzAgi

1108349058576515074.text: Since then I have had no further contact from DigiCert or SDBN but the EV certificate has been revoked: https://crt.sh/?id=995838598&opt=ocsp …pic.twitter.com/K7GyB4cWtY

1108348716187115520.text: DigiCert were quick to respond and followed up asking for more information.pic.twitter.com/7mxQoKf4EO

1108348041684307969.text: I still haven't received any response from the site but I also notified @digicert, who were the issuing CA. They most likely have a point of contact at the organisation in question and also need to revoke the cert now the key is compromised.pic.twitter.com/W5Z7vM71fy

1108347246268088320.text: Of course the immediate course of action was to notify the site and they only had one email address available online to do that.pic.twitter.com/bummqhCYxC

1108346524478722049.text: The folder did indeed contain their EV certificate and the associated private key. https://pastebin.com/Uv6mrNSt pic.twitter.com/WAIgHgAVnl

1108328697675894784.text: Interesting point to note, nobody knows who the CA is!https://twitter.com/Scott_Helme/status/1108307741020426241 …

1093503060897398789.text: Those would be *far* more effective ways to stop the problem. If the domain doesn't exist or won't resolve, who cares about a cert? Killing the cert doesn't stop http (or other) comms, so ultimately won't solve the problem. Why the focus on Let's Encrypt?

1093502623859335169.text: I also don't get the continued focus on the CA (always Let's Encrypt) and the idea of revocation, makes me wonder about ulterior motive. Where is the outrage at registrars to suspend the domain or at DNS providers to not resolve the domain?..

1093501463236620288.text: The criteria to issue should be technical, DV and EV are pretty clear on that. Do you want the CA to decide whether you get a cert, or have one revoked, based on some other arbitrary criteria?https://scotthelme.co.uk/the-power-to-revoke-lies-with-the-ca/ …

1093501191026294785.text: There is of course always the question about how effective revocation is, but ultimately I guess we need and want to fix that, but then avoid it being used in ways that we didn't intend:https://scotthelme.co.uk/revocation-is-broken/ …

1093501027532369921.text: The use of encryption doesn't have a good/bad intention clause, I've spoken about this before and having these sites use certificates can be beneficial:https://scotthelme.co.uk/we-need-more-phishing-sites-on-https/ …

1093500832958611456.text: First of all we don't want CAs to become the moderator of who gets to be online or not. In a 100% encrypted web, the CA would be the ultimate censor.

1060514727699341312.text: There's enough negativity in the world, we don't need to tear each other down. Placing blame helps us determine responsibility and that helps us identify where we need to invest resources to improve. It's not about being nasty and pointing fingers, it's about improving.

1060513521182691328.text: As a user, if I'm responsible for something I will hold my hand up, accept blame, learn from my mistake and work to improve.

1060513323135971328.text: As a site operator, if I'm responsible for something I will hold my hand up, accept blame, learn from my mistake and work to improve.

1060512990024400899.text: Users and site operators need to work together to deliver robust security. That also means that we must both take responsibility, and as a result blame, where it is due.

1060512532979466240.text: No negativity should ever be directed towards a user for their actions. Instead, we should meet their mistakes with help and support.

1060512317245456389.text: We can't say that a user has no responsibility and that we must also educate the user. It's both or neither.
